item.title: Pi-hole Experiment
item.description:
Pi-hole on Azure Virtual Machine

What’s that

I regularly read HackerNews and today I came across an article about a guy who setup his on cloud hosted adblocking DNS server.

I really don’t know anything about Linux and therefore some of the article was a bit technical for me, but I wanted to see if I could get this up and working on Azure.

Goal: Get Pi-hole working on an Azure VM and replace my home internet DNS server with it.

Setup Process

I had to setup and configure a VM in Azure.

  1. Setup a new compute resource using Ubunto Server 16.04 TLS.
    • This was the only Linux distribution Azure offers that’s compatible with Pi-hole.
  2. Install PuTTy to generate a SSH public and private key to access the survey.
  3. Ensure the VM has a static IP address when you are setting it up.
    • This part caught me a few times as the VM settings displays a message that is confusing when you choose ‘Static’ instead of ‘Dynamic.’ I ended up redeploying the VM multiple times trying to resolve the message before ultimately ignoring it because it seemed to not matter.
    • The message was “This static public IP address is associated to the IP configuration ‘ipconfig1’, in the network interface ‘nameofmyazureresourcehere’. You must dissociate it from the network interface before changing its assignment.“
  4. Configure the firewall rules to accept inbound HTTP traffic for the Dashboard and admin portal and DNS traffic to block all the ads.
  5. Connect to the server using PuTTy and install the Pi-hole.
    • I apparently did this in a very risky way, more below.
  6. Connect to my router and change the DNS server the Azure VM I setup.

Results

I was a little nervous switching the DNS server as we live in a mother-in-law and use our extremely generous landlord’s internet. But I knew I could switch it back very quickly so the risk was low.

Pi-hole is amazing. It really works. Ads are blocked not just in your browser, but across any other applications in your system.

Open Items

Some things I want to figure out include:

  • Add picutres and more details to this post.
  • I piped from curl to bash on root which apparently is very risky and not reccomended.
    • Action: Undersatnd what this means and setup a non-root account for a future redeployment or update.
  • I want to more specifically restrict access to the VM, but I understand Comcast using Dynamic IPs and I’m not sure how to add the potential range of addresses for my speicific account and I didn’t want to take the risk of my IP changing and then the internet going down or not working.
  • Figure out how to make it work with my phone’s data plan without using VPN.
    • Currently using ‘DNS Changer’ app for Android which makes this easy.

Resources:

To be updated.

item.title: About
item.description:
This is the first site I’ve created from scratch. It’s a work in progress and I’m primarily using it as a learning tool and to share my experience as I learn data science and web development.

I was originally inspired by Jason Huthinson’s blog after reading his article about a face-replacing slack bot.

This site was created with Hugo and Cocoa-Eh.

As my wife and Yoda both say:

Do or do not, there is no try.

item.title: Creating This Site
item.description:
Step 0: Inspiration

I’ve always wanted to have my own blog or site. But I never really liked the idea of using a service like Medium or Wordpress or Ghost. I wanted my site to be my “own.”

I wanted to dip my toe in web development ocean with the hope of one day scuba diving in it. But I needed inspiration. The site that inspired me on is linked on the about section. I was browsing HackerNews (the exact article is linked in the ‘About’ section), came across an interesting article about a face-replacing slack bot, and was simultaneously struck by the simple and minimal design of the blog.

And from there it snowballed as I rapidly tried to understand:

  • What is Hugo?
    • Oh, it’s a static web site engine.
  • What is a static website engine?
    • I don’t totally understand yet, but I will.
  • Is Hugo the best static website engine for me?
    • Yes, good enough to start. One of the most simple to use.
  • How can I create my own Hugo site on Azure?
    • Let’s “Google” it. Oh this guy did it using Azure Blob Storage.
  • What is Azure Blog Storage?
    • I don’t totally understand yet, but I will.
  • Ok, Azure Blog Storage has too many compatibility issues wiht Hugo and I don’t want to work through them right now, what else can I use to host?
    • I could just use GitHub Pages, but I want to learn more about Azure. Ok, I will use an Azure Web App.

And… here we are. There are a few is a shit ton of other things that I will need to learn more about, but for now I am satisfied with figuring out the basics and hacking it together.

How I Feel Right Now

Learning and creating something - no matter how small - feels good!

Resources

These are some resources that have helped me.

  • Markup Guide
  • Alteranative.to
  • Hugo Quick Start
  • Hugo - Installing on Windows
  • Hugo - Installing Themes
  • StaticGen - List of Static Web Site Generators

Tools I’m Currently Using

  • Visual Studio Code
  • SourceTree
  • BitBucket
  • Azure Web Apps
  • Hugo
  • ConEmu

To Learn List

  • Efficient version control
  • How does a static website generator really work?
  • What is Azure Blob Storage?
  • How do I optimize my current toolset?
  • How do I make publishing as automated as possible?
  • How do I know what parameters are available to me in Hugo (e.g. I can easily create a Twitter link, but not a Facebook or LinkedIn one)?
  • So much more!
